newsitem.title: FRANCE: Lingering strikes hit French air traffic.
newsitem.headline: Lingering strikes hit French air traffic.

text.p: Lingering strikes hit flights in France on Sunday but state railways resumed normal services after a stoppage by train conductors.

Air France Europe cancelled about 40 percent of its flights after some pilots' unions voted to extend a two-day stoppage that began on Friday until Monday evening. "We're expecting the same level of flights tomorrow," a spokeswoman said.
The pilots of the mainly domestic airline have staged a string of stoppages to protest at cuts in their pay and what they say are unacceptable working conditions in a merger with parent Air France.
About a third of the flights were also grounded by a strike by stewards and air hostesses at French units of British Airways, TAT and Air Liberte, officials said.
Pilots at the airlines resumed work at midday after a 17-day strike, saying they had won some concessions on pay and conditions. But the stewards and hostesses extended the stoppage.

Meanwhile, SNCF state railways said traffic was back to normal after conductors in Toulouse, the last bastion of a stoppage by their colleagues originally due to end on Friday, voted to return to work.
The conductors are pushing for higher wages, running against the grain of austerity cuts decreed by the centre-right government of Prime Minister Alain Juppe.
